title: Tim Echols
added: Echols began his time at the Commission looking for ways to help low-income ratepayers <ref>https://psc.ga.gov/site/assets/files/4734/20110119.pdf</ref>.

Echols immediately made an effort to promote alt-fuel vehicles in GA by purchasing a natural gas Honda that he drove back and forth to the Commission from his home in Athens <ref>https://psc.ga.gov/site/assets/files/4735/20110119b.pdf</ref>.

title: Tim Echols
added: Echols says that batteries are capable of extending solar power delivery time beyond sundown.<ref>https://www.ajc.com/politics/politics-blog/opinion-why-a-looming-coal-ash-problem-could-boost-solar-power-in-georgia/E24TO4YAJFACXJYH3BDBLZYFFE/</ref>

title: Tim Echols
added: In 2017, Georgia Trend Magazine named Echols to the list of 100 Most Influential Georgians.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.georgiatrend.com/2017/01/02/100-most-influential-georgians-of-2017-wielding-power/}}</ref> It described Echols as, "a vocal advocate of renewable and clean energy" and mentioned his work on the Clean Energy Roadshow, an annual endeavor that began in 2010 in an effort to highlight alternative-fuel vehicles for both personal and industrial use.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://savannahceo.com/news/2020/08/commissioner-tim-echols-10th-annual-georgia-clean-energy-roadshow-goes-virtual/}}</ref>

Echols has also been noted for his organization of the "Unholy Tour," a bus tour of Atlanta's seedy areas that helps to raise awareness of the cityâ€™s unfortunate reputation as a hub for sex trafficking, particularly of minors.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.ajc.com/news/state--regional/ajc-watchdog-atlanta-sex-trafficking-tour-reveals-the-hell/ckp2tU0uDGYFOpQZl6P3yM/}}</ref>

After years of expanding solar energy in Georgia, Conservatives for Clean Energy called Echols the "Solar Architect of Georgia" in a video interview. <ref>{{cite web |url=https://vimeo.com/460582240}}</ref>
